key_points: Kyle Rittenhouse announced he will attend Arizona State University (ASU) in-person for the spring semester during a podcast appearance.
Arizona State University spokesperson clarified that Rittenhouse has not applied and is welcome to do so like any other applicant.
Rittenhouse previously took a 'compassionate withdrawal' from two online nursing classes at ASU.
There were protests on the ASU campus both against and in support of Rittenhouse's potential attendance.
Rittenhouse was found not guilty on all counts last month for shooting two people at a 2020 protest in Kenosha, Wisconsin.
Rittenhouse claims he is still an admitted student at ASU and possesses a student portfolio, despite not currently taking any classes.
The controversy centers around Rittenhouse's enrollment status at ASU following his trial and acquittal.
Rittenhouse expressed his intent to pursue an undergraduate degree and eventually go to law school.
Jay Thorne, an Arizona State spokesperson, provided a statement regarding Rittenhouse's application status to Forbes.
A representative for Rittenhouse did not immediately respond to Forbes' request for comment.
